subject: swift: Skip long-running dsvm jobs for unrelated changes
commit_message:
swift: Skip long-running dsvm jobs for unrelated changes

Several classes of change do not benefit from dsvm functional tests:

 - unit test changes (which are tested by gate-swift-python27-ubuntu-xenial
   and gate-swift-tox-xfs-tmp-py27-ubuntu-xenial),
 - general documentation changes (which are tested by
   gate-swift-docs-ubuntu-xenial),
 - release note changes (which are tested by gate-swift-releasenotes),
 - api-ref changes (which are tested by gate-swift-api-ref), and
 - install guide changes (which are tested by gate-swift-install-guide).

Continuing to run dsvm tests for changes that are purely in some
combination of the above categories has several downsides:

 - It wastes shared infrastructure, and for not-insignificant amounts of
   time. (gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full-ubuntu-xenial takes more than an
   hour; gate-grenade-dsvm-neutron-ubuntu-xenial just over half an hour.)
 - It increases wall-time for the gate to give feedback to contributors.
   The longest-running jobs excluding the dsvm jobs complete in 5-7
   minutes; by waiting an additional hour to provide a Verified vote, we
   are assured that authors have context-switched.
 - Between intermittent gate failures and context-switching, reviewed
   changes may take multiple days to actually merge [1].

This change will skip the dsvm tests for swift changes that only touch
the above-mentioned subtrees. As noted, all such changes will still be
properly tested, and we will always run at least one test.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/457776/

subject: Perform an atomic policy file change
commit_message:
Perform an atomic policy file change

The policy.json file is currently read continually by the
services and is not only read on service start. We therefore
cannot template directly to the file read by the service
(if the service is already running) because the new policies
may not be valid until the service restarts. This is
particularly important during a major upgrade. We therefore
only put the policy file in place after the service restart.

This patch also tidies up the handlers and some of the install
tasks to simplify them and reduce the tasks/code a little.

subject: Optimizing lang schema validation
commit_message:
Optimizing lang schema validation

* Before this patch some language specification schemas were
  validated twice (or even more) because some parent specs had
  references to specific schemas of child specs in their schemas.
  And due to our recursive parsing algorithm the same schemas were
  checked many times. It reduces performance and complicates
  the entire lang specification framework because there's too many
  relationships between different specs. The better approach is to
  reduce a number of relationships. One way is to not check schemas
  child specs when checking parent spec schema. This patch removes
  such references replacing them just common schemas like
  "non-empty" or "any" which don't lead to validating sub-schemas
  when validating parent schemas.

commit_message:
Modify log marker functions's usage in an exception

The log marker functions (_LI(), _LW(), _LE(), and _LC()) must only be used when the message is only sent directly to the log. Anytime that the message will be passed outside of the current context (for example as part of an exception) the _() marker function must be used.
Ref: https://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html
For example:
msg = _LE('There was an error.')
LOG.exception(msg)
raise LocalExceptionClass(msg)
Instead, use this style:

msg = _('There was an error.')
raise LocalExceptionClass(msg)

subject: Only add "on-link" routes for L2 adjacent subnets
commit_message:
Only add "on-link" routes for L2 adjacent subnets

When multiple subnets exist on a single network, the
DHCP agent adds on-link routes for all of them since
they are in the same L2 network.  If either subnet
has a segment_id it can only be considered as on-link
if they match, else we should not include a subnet
route.

These extra routes are optional anyways according to
RFC 3442, but were added for the use case when all of
the subnets are considered adjacent, which allows
instances to bypass the router and communicate directly.

subject: Do not sync suffixes when remote rejects reconstructor revert
commit_message:
Do not sync suffixes when remote rejects reconstructor revert

SSYNC is designed to limit concurrent incoming connections in order to
prevent IO contention.  The reconstructor should expect remote
replication servers to fail ssync_sender when the remote is too busy.
When the remote rejects SSYNC - it should avoid forcing additional IO
against the remote with a REPLICATE request which causes suffix
rehashing.

Suffix rehashing via REPLICATE verbs takes two forms:

1) a initial pre-flight call to REPLICATE /dev/part will cause a remote
primary to rehash any invalid suffixes and return a map for the local
sender to compare so that a sync can be performed on any mis-matched
suffixes.

2) a final call to REPLICATE /dev/part/suf1-suf2-suf3[-sufX[...]] will
cause the remote primary to rehash the *given* suffixes even if they are
*not* invalid.  This is a requirement for rsync replication because
after a suffix is synced via rsync the contents of a suffix dir will
likely have changed and the remote server needs to update it hashes.pkl
to reflect the new data.

SSYNC does not *need* to send a post-sync REPLICATE request.  Any
suffixes that are modified by the SSYNC protocol will call _finalize_put
under the hood as it is syncing.  It is however not harmful and
potentially useful to go ahead refresh hashes after an SSYNC while the
inodes of those suffixes are warm in the cache.

However, that only makes sense if the SSYNC conversation actually synced
any suffixes - if SSYNC is rejected for concurrency before it ever got
started there is no value in the remote performing a rehash.  It may be
that *another* reconstructor is pushing data into that same partition
and the suffixes will become immediately invalidated.

If a ssync_sender does not successful finish a sync the reconstructor
should skip the REPLICATE call entirely and move on to the next
partition without causing any useless remote IO.

Closes-Bug: #1665141

Change-Id: Ia72c407247e4525ef071a1728750850807ae8231

subject: neutron-lib incubating periodic hacking checks
commit_message:
neutron-lib incubating periodic hacking checks

As per the discussion in [1], we need a neutron-lib
periodic job that can run neutron-lib "incubating"
hacking checks. The goal of this job is to inform
consumers of upcoming checks and allow them time
to adopt the upcoming checks. As such the periodic
job should be run as non-voting; failures can be easily
flagged, but don't inhibit workflow.

This patch introduces a periodic job that's part of the
periodic-python-jobs-with-neutron-lib-master job group
to carry out that goal.

Specifically:
- A new helper script is defined to carry out the execution.
This script must update the [hacking] section of tox.ini
to use a said local-check-factory.
- A corresponding job template that's added to the neutron-lib
master job group. This job is non-voting as noted above.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/350723/

subject: Support interactive mode for exec command
commit_message:
Support interactive mode for exec command

The support of interactive execute is similar to attach but
the docker exec endpoint doesn't support websocket as the attach
endpoint. Therefore, this commit introduced an HTTP client for
streaming. The common code between websocketclient and HTTP
client are consolidated into a base class.

This patch relies on the server to return the URL of Docker
Engine [1] and leverage the URL to connect to the container and
execute commands interactively. A sample workflow would be as
following.

1. Create a container that never exited (by using the command
   "tail -f /dev/null"):
   [host]$ zun run --name test ubuntu tail -f /dev/null

2. Enter the container with a Bash shell:
   [host]$ zun exec -i test bash

3. Once you are inside, you can run any command you want:
   [container]# apt-get update

4. Once finished, exit the container:
   [container]# exit

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/452505/

subject: Add sha384 and sha512 auth algorithms for vendor drivers
commit_message:
Add sha384 and sha512 auth algorithms for vendor drivers

Currently, VPNaaS limits the IPSec and IKE auth algorithm to
"sha1" and "sha256". If user add a new driver(eg, Hardware VPN Gateway),
and the new driver supports more auth algorithms, such as "sha2-384",
"sha2-512", it can not integrated with current VPNaaS plugin.

This patch add "sha384" and "sha512" auth algorithms in API and DB side,
Because of Openswan, Strongswan, Libreswan and Cisco CSR driver doesn't
support these, so we add a validator in ipsec and Cisco CSR service driver,
that will raise an exception when creating or updating the IPSec/IKE Policy
auth algorithm with "sha384" and "sha512".
Other vendors can bypass validate ike_policy and ipsec_policy
when creating and updating auth_algorithm, or implement specific
logic for themselves.

subject: Fixes retrieving row_by_record for ports on Windows
commit_message:
Fixes retrieving row_by_record for ports on Windows

On Windows the name of the ports are UUIDs (for Windows
there is no 16 chars length limitation as for Linux).

Since the string is a UUID, it will not fail when it will
try to convert it with 'uuid.UUID(record)'. After this it
will try to fetch the row directly which will raise a
KeyError exception on Windows.

This does not happen on Linux because the port names
have a 16 chars length limitation. The limitation does not
apply in the Windows case. On Linux it will fail at the line
with 'uuid.UUID(record)' which will raise a ValueError
exception and will continue to lookup by other means.

This patch addresses this issue by removing the exception
RowNotFound in the Windows case.
